channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-12869] Add a REST API implementation of the ClusterManager interface
item.description: ChaosMonkey doesn't work on HBase/CDH clusters set up using Cloudera Manager because Cloudera Manager doesn't make use of hbase-daemon.sh (so killed RegionServers can't be started up again). To fix this, I want to implement ClouderaManagerClusterManager. I could just as well keep this internal (or only include it in Cloudera's distribution), but seeing as how it would open up more people across the community to run hbase-it, I'd like to commit it upstream. Anyone object?
item.summary: Add a REST API implementation of the ClusterManager interface

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: -0 to making any vendor specific commits to the Apache project. From the community perspective, the fact that ChaosMonkey doesn't work with CM is a CM bug, I think.

Can purge vendor reference, np. Can call it something else: e.g. "Implementation of ClusterManager where start scripts are in alternate location". I believe the idea is to remove barriers running hbase-it on deploys other than hand-crafted apache hadoop setups. Follow-ons I can see happening would be ambari version (there was talk of such an animal at one time) and one for bigtop.

Can purge vendor reference, np. Can call it something else: e.g. "Implementation of ClusterManager where start scripts are in alternate location"

+1
Other plus is we'll have illustration of how to provide a ClusterManager other than the packaged one.

The trouble is Cloudera Manager (just like Ambari) has a Java API to use, so it's not just a matter of changing start script locations. As I said, I'm fine keeping it out of the project, but it just means more hurdles to people using hbase-it.

Sorry to say it, but Ambari would be a different animal being an open source Apache project. Perhaps something built for Ambari could have a dual purpose? And it wouldn't necessarily need to be called "AmbariClusterManager".

Hm... how about if I contributed a RESTApiClusterManager? It could just be an adapter where users could specify the start and stop commands via hbase-site, and then it would execute them? Such an implementation would work for both Cloudera Manager and Ambari. That more acceptable?
Sounds good, thanks for being flexible.

So I spent a few days investigating the possibility of implementing a single "RESTApiClusterManager" class and realized it can't be done in a very clean way. In short, the different APIs (i.e. Cloudera Manager, Ambari) have very different ways of running commands (e.g. Cloudera Manager acts on host IDs, which need a separate API call to discover from a hostname, but that requires parsing JSON). So two ways forward:

1) I can Implement RESTApiClusterManager1 that's Cloudera Manager-specific, but which doesn't bring in any Cloudera dependencies and only specifies that it's for Cloudera Manager in a comment. This has the advantage of being an example for others who want to see how ClusterManager can be implemented and would open the door for anyone interested in modifying and creating RESTApiClusterManager2 that can handle Ambari.
2) Just close this out as won't fix and let each user deal with implementing the interface themselves if they want to run integration tests.

What do you think, Andrew Purtell?

Thanks for doing the investigation Dima Spivak. Implementing a single "RESTApiClusterManager" that for the time being only works with the Cloudera Manager is fine in my opinion. The project has asked for and gotten as neutral an implementation as is feasible. RESTApiClusterManager can be extended at some future time to handle alternate interfaces. For example there could be nested interfaces like Request and Response that could be implemented for a different API and configured in.
Renaming the JIRA to reflect the fact that this will be an implementation via REST API. This means it could be extended to handle other RESTful cluster managers (e.g. Ambari), as needed.

Here's my first attempt at a RESTApiClusterManager implementation. As stated in the comments, it works with Cloudera Manager out of the box, but could be extended and/or modified in a relatively straightforward way to support something like Apache Ambari, as well.
Post patch here Dima Spivak Lets get a test run in. I need to review what you have over in RB again?

Will do, stack. Probably no need for another review; just addressed your comments and sorted out an issue with GenericOptionsParser by having it do what HBaseClusterManager does around extending Configured. Will post master patch here momentarily...
Posting master patch for QA bot.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12698804/HBASE-12869_master_v2.patch
against master branch at commit a98898cf417de71c7250acd0a1c107101c3bb487.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 3 new or modified tests.
+1 hadoop versions. The patch compiles with all supported hadoop versions (2.4.1 2.5.2 2.6.0)

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

And here's a patch against 0.98 (since before ClusterManager's interface was changed to require specification of ports to support multiple RSs).

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Adds an implementation of ClusterManager to control REST API-managed HBase clusters.
